{{Quote|It sits on the shelf. We have 50 hours. We are trying to figure out a different way of making movies. We are looking for a different technology that we can use, that will make it economically feasible to shoot the show. Right now, it looks like the Star Wars features. But we have to figure out how to make it at about a tenth of the cost of the features, because its television. We are working toward that, and we continue to work towards that. We will get there at some point. It's just a very difficult process. Obviously, when we do figure this problem out, it will dramatically effect features, because feature films are costing between $250 to $350 million. When we figure this out, they will be able to make a feature film for $50 million.|George Lucas|<ref name="LucasMovieWeb">{{WebCite|url=http://movieweb.com/star-wars-3d-and-live-action-tv-series-update-from-george-lucas|text=Star Wars 3D and Live Action TV Series Update from George Lucas|author=B. Alan Orange|date=2011-05-25|work=[[Wikipedia:MovieWeb|MovieWeb]]|archivedate=20170318140323}}</ref>}}
'''''Star Wars: Underworld''''' is the working title of a proposed live-action television series that would be set during the timespan between the films [[Star Wars: Episode III Revenge of the Sith|''Star Wars'': Episode III ''Revenge of the Sith'']] and [[Star Wars: Episode IV A New Hope|''Star Wars'': Episode IV ''A New Hope'']]. [[George Lucas]] first announced the series at [[2005]]'s [[Celebration III]]. Over the next few years, a variety of writers were hired, over fifty scripts were written and art designers worked on visualizing Lucas' ideas. However, in [[2010]], Lucas announced that the series was on hold due to budget constraints.

==Plot summary==
{{Quote|It's kind of like ''Episode IV'' — it's funny and there's action, but it's [a] lot more talky. It's more of what I would call a soap opera with a bunch of personal dramas in it. It's not really based on action-adventure films from the '30s — it's actually more based on film noir movies from the '40s!|George Lucas|<ref name="TF 140">{{BookCite|text=[[Wikipedia:Total Film|Total Film]]|number=Isssue 140|publisher=[[Wikipedia:Future plc|Future plc]]|date=2008-05}} {{C|[[:File:TotalFilmMagazine-Issue140-p138.jpg|Archived here]]}}</ref>}}
''Star Wars: Underworld'' is said to be set primarily in the [[Coruscant Underworld]] (which was briefly glimpsed during [[Star Wars: Episode II Attack of the Clones|''Star Wars'': Episode II ''Attack of the Clones'']]), in the time period between [[Star Wars: Episode III Revenge of the Sith|''Star Wars'': Episode III ''Revenge of the Sith'']] and [[Star Wars: Episode IV A New Hope|''Star Wars'': Episode IV ''A New Hope'']].<ref name="TFN1-9-12">{{WebCite|url=http://www.theforce.net/latestnews/story/LiveAction_Series_Working_Title_Revealed_142924.asp|text=Live-Action Series Working Title Revealed|date=2012-01-09|work=[[TheForce.net]]|archivedate=20200101224640}}</ref> It is during this period that the [[Galactic Empire]] rises to ultimate power throughout [[the galaxy]].<ref name="inn">{{InsiderCite|99|Com-Scan}}</ref> In [[2005]], [[George Lucas]] told [[Celebration III]] audiences that the show would not focus on any characters from the films, but that some of them could appear;<ref name="C3S2">{{Hyperspace|url=hyperspace/member/audiocast/audio/SW_celebrationiii_02_2005-07-29.mp3|text=Celebration III George Lucas Session 2}}</ref> "A lot of the issues from the films are connected, but you won't necessarily see a lot of the people that are connected."<ref name="maker">{{SWArchive|url=community/event/celebration/f20050419/indexp17.html|text=starwars.com at Celebration III – Thank the Maker: George Lucas}}</ref> He later described the show as "bare-bones" and "action-heavy,"<ref name="USA Today">{{WebCite|url=https://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/people/2007-04-04-george-lucas_N.htm|text=He has a need for speed|author=William Keck|date=2007-04-04|work=[[Wikipedia:USA Today|''USA Today'']]|archivedate=20190225194716}}</ref> and explained that it would depict what the inhabitants of the ''[[Star Wars]]'' galaxy do for entertainment.<ref>{{WebCite|url=http://www.ugo.com/ugo/html/article/?id=558&sectionId=2|text=Star Wars: The Clone Wars Interviews|author=Adam Swiderski|work=[[Wikipedia:UGO Networks|UGO]]|archivedate=20100814141523}}</ref>

Producer [[Rick McCallum]] commented on the plot of the series: "[Lucas] envisions somewhere like 100 hours between Episode III and Episode IV with a lot of characters that we haven't met that have been developed in some of the novels and other things. We are really excited about that. Finally, we could have the opportunity to answer everybody's questions once and for all by the time we finish the series.";<ref name="RM">{{Hyperspace|url=hyperspace/member/audiocast/audio/SW_dvdpressevent_02_2005-10-07.mp3|text=Rick McCallum at ROTS press conference}}</ref> "It is going to be much darker, grittier. It's much more character-based";<ref name="RM" /> "Think about bounty hunter, that's all I can tell you."<ref>{{WebCite|url=http://www.ifmagazine.com/feature.asp?article=1492|text=Exclusive Interview: ''STAR WARS'' PRODUCER RICK MCCALLUM TALKS 3D & TV SERIES|author=Sean Elliott|date=2006-05-10|work=IFMagazine|archivedate=20061024005654|nolive=1}}</ref> He also called it "[[Wikipedia:Deadwood (TV series)|''Deadwood'']] in space" and "[[Star Wars: Episode V The Empire Strikes Back|''Empire'']] on steroids,"<ref name="COL (2012/01)">{{WebCite|url=https://collider.com/rick-mccallum-red-tails-star-wars-tv-series-interview/138426|text=Producer Rick McCallum Talks RED TAILS and Live-Action STAR WARS TV Series; Describes Show as "EMPIRE STRIKES BACK on Steroids"|author=Steve Weintraub|date=2012-01-18|work=[[Wikipedia:Collider (website)|''Collider'']]|archivedate=20200108120602}}</ref> and compared it to [[Wikipedia:The Godfather|''The Godfather'']].<ref name="Czechposition.com">{{WebCite|url=http://www.ceskapozice.cz/en/business/companies/star-wars-tv-series-may-shoot-prague|text=Star Wars TV series may shoot in Prague|author=Raymond Johnston|date=2011-06-10|work=Czech Position|archivedate=20110613052634|nolive=1}}</ref> [[Lucasfilm Ltd.|Lucasfilm's]] [[Stephen J. Sansweet]] also described the series as revealing the "greasy, seamy underbelly of Star Wars."<ref name="mtv">{{WebCite|url=http://moviesblog.mtv.com/2008/04/20/star-wars-live-action-show-to-reveal-galaxys-greasy-seamy-underbelly|text='Star Wars' Live-Action Show To Reveal Galaxy's 'Greasy, Seamy Underbelly'|author=Josh Horowitz|date=2008-04-20|work=[[Wikipedia:MTV|MTV]]|archivedate=20150905210426}}</ref> Writer [[Ronald D. Moore]] said that it would've generally followed one overarching story, and described it as "...lots of action, lots of sets, and huge set pieces. Just much bigger than what you would normally do in a television show."<ref name="Moore 2020">{{WebCite|url=https://collider.com/star-wars-underworld-live-action-series-details-ronald-d-moore-george-lucas|text=Exclusive: Ronald D. Moore Gives Details on George Lucas' Scrapped Live-Action 'Star Wars' TV Series|author=Tom Reimann|date=2020-05-24|work=[[Wikipedia:Collider (website)|''Collider'']]|archivedate=20200621133822}}</ref>

According to Dan Wasson, project leader for the [[Wikipedia: Nintendo Wii|Wii]] version of the ''[[Star Wars: The Force Unleashed]]'', the TV series may contain elements from the overall [[Star Wars: The Force Unleashed|''Star Wars: The Force Unleashed'' multimedia project]].<ref>{{WebCite|url=http://www.theforce.net/latestnews/story/The_Force_Unleashed_PreReview_111889.asp|text=The Force Unleashed – Pre-Review|date=2008-01-28|work=[[TheForce.net]]|archivedate=20190219125111}}</ref> In [[2014]], [[Stephen Scaia]] revealed in his [[Wikipedia: Kickstarter|Kickstarter]] campaign that he had been a writer for the series, and was involved in several story elements, including [[Landonis Balthazar Calrissian|Lando Calrissian]] losing the ''[[Millennium Falcon]]'' to [[Han Solo]], Solo and [[Chewbacca]]'s first meeting, as well as an action scene with [[Boba Fett]].<ref name="Scaia Kickstarter" /><ref name="TFN Scaia" />

==Cast and characters==
{{Quote|It was going to tell the story of a different part of the ''Star Wars'' universe that you didn't exactly know, and then it was going to slowly fold back into the characters that you knew and loved.|Stephen Scaia|<ref name="Scaia Kickstarter" />}}
The series was expected to feature minor characters from both the films and the [[Star Wars Legends|Expanded Universe]]—with possible [[Wikipedia:Cameo appearance|cameos]] by some of the main characters.<ref>{{Hyperspace|url=hyperspace/member/audiocast/audio/SW_celebrationiii_01_2005-07-29.mp3|text=Celebration III George Lucas Session 1}}</ref> Lucas: "[[Darth Sidious|The Emperor]] and [[Anakin Skywalker|Darth Vader]] are heard about—people talk about them—but you never see them because it doesn't take place where they actually are. There are stormtroopers and all that, but there are no [[Jedi]]s."<ref name="2TV">{{WebCite|url=http://www.tvguide.com/news/lucas-wars-TV/070920-01|text=George Lucas on his two Star Wars TV series, Heroes and HBO's Rome|author=Steve Sonsky|date=2007-09-20|work=[[Wikipedia:TV Guide|TV Guide]]|archivedate=20080921193236}}</ref> However, as the show was being written, some of these characters appeared in the scripts. Former [[LucasArts]] developer Cory Barlog revealed he read ''Underworld'' scripts at [[Skywalker Ranch]] for episodes featuring Palpatine, where "They made the Emperor a sympathetic figure who was wronged by this […] heartless woman. She's this hardcore gangster, and she just totally destroyed him as a person. I almost cried while reading this. This is the Emperor, the lightning out of the fingers Emperor. That's something magical".<ref name="Barlog">{{WebCite|url=https://venturebeat.com/2016/06/15/that-cancelled-star-wars-live-action-show-inspired-the-new-god-of-war|text=That canceled Star Wars live-action show inspired the new God of War|author=Mike Minotti|date=2016-06-15|work=[[Wikipedia:VentureBeat|''VentureBeat'']]|archivedate=20200610001054}}</ref> Writer [[Ronald D. Moore]] said that Vader "was going to show up for a big two-part episode where there was this big uprising happening, and there was a crack-down on things that were happening on Coruscant. Vader shows up and is kind of like, 'We're gonna stop all this shit right now.'"<ref name="Moore-inverse">{{WebCite|url=https://www.inverse.com/article/31178-star-wars-underworld-battlestar-ron-moore-darth-vader-may-4|text='Battlestar' Showrunner Reveals His Unaired Darth Vader Story|author=Ryan Britt|date=2017-05-04|work=[[Wikipedia:Inverse (website)|''Inverse'']]|archivedate=20200604230554}}</ref>

Lucas had originally written a scene for ''Revenge of the Sith'' involving the Expanded Universe character [[Quinlan Vos]],<ref>''[[The Art of Star Wars Episode III: Revenge of the Sith]]''</ref> but the character received only a mention in the final film.<ref>{{Film|III}}</ref> Lucas himself later instructed the writers of the ''[[Star Wars: Republic]]'' comic book series to ''not'' kill off the character. This has led some fans to speculate that Vos may play a role in the series,<ref name="JCF1">{{JCFCite|url=posts/21006027|board=Literature|thread=Republic #83: The Hidden Enemy, part 3 (of 3)|user=RevantheJediMaster|date=2005-08-03|time=7:35 AM|archiveurl=https://archive.vn/r7g6E}}</ref> although ''Republic'' writer [[Randy Stradley]] later clarified that he wasn't sure if the character would have appeared and had heard that a different character to Vos might have appeared.<ref>{{Twitter|Randy_Stradley|status/929959039374471168|[[Randy Stradley]]|quote=Never heard that Vos was for sure going to appear in the show. In fact, I'd heard it might be a different character entirely.|archivefile=File:RStadleyNov122017.png}}</ref> In an interview in the November 2005 edition of the UK magazine ''Total Film'' magazine, McCallum was asked "How can [[Leia Skywalker Organa Solo|Leia]] claim to remember her mother when [[Padmé Amidala|Padmé]] dies in childbirth in ''Sith''?," to which he replied "I think that could only be answered in the television series."<ref>{{BookCite|title=[[Wikipedia:Total Film|''Total Film'']]|number=108|publisher=[[Wikipedia:Future plc|Future plc]]|date=November 2005}}</ref> After being impressed by her work on ''[[The Han Solo Trilogy]]'', Lucasfilm asked [[A. C. Crispin]] for her ideas on possible further books.<ref>{{WebCite|url=http://unreality-sf.net/2004/12/29/a-c-crispin-fan-q-and-a|text=A.C. Crispin interview|date=2004-12-29|work=[http://unreality-sf.net Unreality SF]|archivedate=20160914155456}}</ref> She proposed a book series that would have focused on Leia between ''Revenge of the Sith'' and ''A New Hope'', but "Lucasfilm didn't approve the idea of a Leia backstory because they want to keep that era of the SW continuity untouched for the television series they're considering."<ref name="JCF2">{{JCFCite|url=posts/23997999|board=Literature|thread=Author Analysis: Ann C. Crispin|user=accrispin|date=2006-05-29|time=9:19 AM|archivedate=20160311000108}}</ref> [[Karen Traviss]] was to write a [[Untitled Boba Fett novel|novel involving Boba Fett]], but the project was reportedly canceled because of possible conflicts with the TV series.<ref>{{WebCite|url=https://io9.gizmodo.com/is-it-too-late-to-save-the-imperial-commandos-5466313|text=Is It Too Late To Save The Imperial Commandos?|author=Charlie Jane Anders|date=2010-12-02|work=[[Wikipedia:io9|''io9'']]|archivedate=20200603012620}}</ref> [[John Jackson Miller]] had been developing a graphic novel for [[Dark Horse Comics]] starring [[Obi-Wan Kenobi/Legends|Obi-Wan Kenobi]] in a [[Wikipedia:Western (genre)|Western]]-like story, but had struggled pitching the project to his ''[[Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic]]'' editor [[Jeremy Barlow]] and the two eventually agreed to shelve the project after hearing rumors in [[April]] or [[May]] 2007 about the show moving forward, not wishing to potentially conflict with any Kenobi-centric ideas Lucas could have been developing for the show. Miller's story was eventually released as the novel ''[[Kenobi (novel)|Kenobi]]'' in [[2013]].<ref>{{WebCite|url=https://www.forcecast.net/story/indycast/IndyCast_Episode_265_180796.asp|text=IndyCast: Episode 265|date=2018-05-21|work=[[The ForceCast]]|archivedate=20200201094719}}</ref> 

Multiple actors from the films had expressed interest in reprising their roles: [[Jeremy Bulloch]] ([[Boba Fett]]),<ref>{{InsiderCite|117|Interrogation Droid!}}</ref> [[Jay Laga'aia]] ([[Gregar Typho]]),<ref name="kiwi">{{WebCite|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/entertainment/2273899/Kiwi-eyes-role-in-Star-Wars|text=Kiwi eyes role in Star Wars|author=The Dominion Post|date=2009-06-18|work=[[Wikipedia:Stuff (company)|Stuff]]|archivedate=20100828084436}}</ref> [[Daniel Logan]] (young Boba Fett),<ref name="gala">{{WebCite|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/people/2005-06-12-afi-star-wars_x.htm|text=Lucas: Man of the gala|author=William Keck|date=2005-06-12|work=[[Wikipedia:USA Today|''USA Today'']]|archivedate=20160414024954}}</ref><ref>{{WebCite|url=http://starwars.ugo.com/dvds/starwars_revengeofthesith/mccallum.asp|text=Star Wars Producer Rick McCallum Interview|author=Reg Seeton; Troy Rogers|work=[[Wikipedia:UGO Networks|UGO]]|archivedate=20051128230139|nolive=1}}</ref><ref name="toche">{{WebCite|url=http://www.toschestation.nl/interviews/interview-rickmccallum.php|text=Interviews – Rick McCallum|work=Tosche Station|archivedate=20070429004637|nolive=1}}</ref><ref name="Reunion2">{{WebCite|url=http://www.theforce.net/latestnews/story/Rick_McCallum_Talks_Star_Wars_On_TV_109774.asp|text=Rick McCallum Talks ''Star Wars'' On TV|author=Mike Barrick|date=2007-11-08|work=[[TheForce.net]]|archivedate=20160422110230}}</ref><ref name="inn" /><ref name="gala" /><ref name="NYCC07">{{WebCite|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2007/02/24/nycc-07-star-wars-behind-the-mask|text=NYCC 07: Star Wars -- Behind The Mask|author=Steven Horn|date=2007-02-23|work=[[Wikipedia:IGN|''IGN'']]|archivedate=20180513095826}}</ref> [[Peter Mayhew]] ([[Chewbacca]]),<ref name="NYCC07" /> and [[Ian McDiarmid]] (The Emperor).<ref>{{Hyperspace|url=hyperspace/member/audiocast/audio/SW_dvdpressevent_04_2005-10-12.mp3|text=Ian McDiarmid Q&A: DVD Press Event}}</ref><ref>{{WebCite|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2012/08/24/ian-mcdiarmid-on-possibly-playing-the-emperor-in-the-live-action-star-wars-tv-series|text=Ian McDiarmid on Possibly Playing The Emperor in the Live-Action Star Wars TV Series|date=2012-08-23|work=IGN.com|archivedate=20180725111618}}</ref> For a time, Logan underwent physical training with [[Ray Park]] ([[Maul|Darth Maul]]), in anticipation of reprising his role as Boba Fett,<ref>{{SWYouTube|video=oEnzNutWZJE|text=Keeping Up With The Fetts Panel | Star Wars Celebration Europe 2016}}</ref> while in the other hand, Bulloch also expressed interest in play an alter ego of Boba Fett, as he thought that Logan would play him in the series due his age.<ref>{{WebCite|url=https://starwarsinterviews.com/original-trilogy/episode-v-the-empire-strikes-back/jeremy-bulloch-boba-fett|text=Jeremy Bulloch (Boba Fett)|author=[[Dennis Pellegrom]]|date=2006-05|work=[[Star Wars Interviews]]|archivedate=20230205201435|nolive=1}}</ref> [[Star Wars: Episode I The Phantom Menace|''The Phantom Menace'']] actors [[Andrew Secombe]], [[Lewis MacLeod]] and [[Christian Simpson]] had also expressed interest in reprising their roles as [[Watto]], [[Sebulba]] and [[Gavyn Sykes/Legends|Gavyn Sykes]], respectively, for the series.<ref>{{WebCite|url=https://starwarsinterviews.com/prequel-trilogy/episode-i-the-phantom-menace/andy-secombe-watto|text=Andy Secombe (Watto)|author=[[Dennis Pellegrom]]|date=2006-05|work=[[Star Wars Interviews]]|archivedate=20220930171401|nolive=1}}</ref><ref>{{WebCite|url=https://starwarsinterviews.com/prequel-trilogy/episode-i-the-phantom-menace/lewis-mcleod-sebulba|text=Lewis McLeod (Sebulba)|author=[[Dennis Pellegrom]]|date=2010-01|work=[[Star Wars Interviews]]|archivedate=20220930150613|nolive=1}}</ref><ref>{{Blog|bravo|22/comments|Making Episode III: 31 Jan 2005 - 'The Force binds the galaxy together'|nobackup=1}}</ref> On the other hand, however, [[Billy Dee Williams]] refused to reprise his role as [[Landonis Balthazar Calrissian|Lando Calrissian]], nor play the character's uncle, although he hinted in [[2005]] that he could return to play Lando as an older man,<ref>{{WebCite|url=https://starwarsinterviews.com/original-trilogy/episode-v-the-empire-strikes-back/billy-dee-williams-lando-calrissian|text=Billy Dee Williams (Lando Calrissian)|author=[[Dennis Pellegrom]]|date=2005-09|work=[[Star Wars Interviews]]|archivedate=20221118183151|nolive=1}}</ref> as he presumably didn't know in which place of the timeline the series would be set. In 2006, [[Toby Philpott]], who co-puppeted [[Jabba Desilijic Tiure|Jabba the Hutt]] in [[Star Wars: Episode VI Return of the Jedi|''Return of the Jedi'']], doubted very much that he could reprise his role, as he supposed that the series would be made in the USA.<ref>{{WebCite|url=https://starwarsinterviews.com/original-trilogy/episode-vi-return-of-the-jedi/toby-philpott-jabba-the-hutt|text=Toby Philpott (Jabba the Hutt)|author=[[Dennis Pellegrom]]|date=2006|work=[[Star Wars Interviews]]|archivedate=20230205201613|nolive=1}}</ref> Conversely, that same year, various actors who appeared in ''Jedi'' had expressed interest in reprising their roles for the series: [[Tim Dry]] ([[J'Quille]]),<ref>{{WebCite|url=https://starwarsinterviews.com/original-trilogy/episode-vi-return-of-the-jedi/tim-dry-whiphid|text=Tim Dry (Whiphid)|author=[[Dennis Pellegrom]]|date=2006|work=[[Star Wars Interviews]]|archivedate=20230205201613|nolive=1}}</ref> [[Mercedes Ngoh]] ([[Rystáll Sant]], in the film's [[1997]] DVD release),<ref>{{WebCite|url=https://starwarsinterviews.com/original-trilogy/episode-vi-return-of-the-jedi/mercedes-ngoh-rystall|text=Mercedes N'goh (Rystáll)|author=[[Dennis Pellegrom]]|date=2006|work=[[Star Wars Interviews]]|archivedate=20230205201613|nolive=1}}</ref> [[Mike Quinn]] ([[Nien Nunb]], [[Ten Numb]], [[Wokling]], Ree-Yees, [[Wol Cabasshite]] and [[Sy Snootles]]),<ref name="Mike Quinn Interview OT">{{WebCite|url=https://starwarsinterviews.com/original-trilogy/mike-quinn-nien-nunb|text=Mike Quinn (Nien Nunb)|author=[[Dennis Pellegrom]]|date=2006|work=[[Star Wars Interviews]]|archivedate=20220930161216|nolive=1}}</ref> and [[Simon Williamson]] ([[Max Rebo]] and [[Jubnuk]]).<ref>{{WebCite|url=https://starwarsinterviews.com/original-trilogy/episode-vi-return-of-the-jedi/simon-j-williamson-max-rebo|text=Simon J. Williamson (Max Rebo)|author=[[Dennis Pellegrom]]|date=2006|work=[[Star Wars Interviews]]|archivedate=20230205202912|nolive=1}}</ref> In [[January]] [[2010]], [[Paul Blake]] stated during an interview that he would like very much to reprise his role as [[Greedo]] in the series, although he hadn't been contacted so far to do so.<ref>{{WebCite|url=https://starwarsinterviews.com/original-trilogy/episode-iv-a-new-hope/paul-blake-greedo|text=Paul Blake (Greedo)|author=[[Dennis Pellegrom]]|date=2010-01|work=[[Star Wars Interviews]]|archivedate=20230205202901|nolive=1}}</ref>

Members of the cast outside the films (or those who played minor roles in the films) had also expressed interest in appearing in the series; ''Star Wars: The Force Unleashed'' actor [[Sam Witwer]] wanted to appear (possibly as [[Galen Marek]], Vader's secret apprentice), and hinted in an interview that he would indeed be involved.<ref>{{SWArchive|url=gaming/videogames/news/news20070515.html|text=Meet the Stars of ''Star Wars'': The Force Unleashed}}</ref><ref name="Up Close: Sam Witwer">{{WebCite|url=http://www.wizarduniverse.com/magazine/toyfare/006564394.cfm|text=Close: Sam Witwer|author=Andy Livingston|date=2007-12-04|work=[[Wikipedia:Wizard Entertainment|Wizard Entertainment]]|archivedate=20080107024821|nolive=1}}</ref> Likewise, [[Adrienne Wilkinson]] showed interest in seeing her character of [[Maris Brood]] in the series.<ref>{{WebCite|url=https://starwarsinterviews.com/various/lucasarts/adrienne-wilkinson-maris-brood|text=Adrienne Wilkinson (Maris Brood - The Force Unleashed)|author=[[Dennis Pellegrom]]|date=2010-03|work=[[Star Wars Interviews]]|archivedate=20230205201532|nolive=1}}</ref> In [[2007]], [[Shannon McRandle]], who modeled as [[Mara Jade Skywalker]] for the ''Star Wars'' card games, expressed her desire to audition to play the role of Jade in the series in order to develop her between Episodes III and IV.<ref>{{WebCite|url=https://starwarsinterviews.com/various/expanded-universe/shannon-mcrandle-mara-jade|text=Shannon McRandle (Mara Jade)|author=[[Dennis Pellegrom]]|date=2007|work=[[Star Wars Interviews]]|archivedate=20220930151637|nolive=1}}</ref> On [[March 9]], [[2009]], actress [[Rose Byrne]], who appeared in ''Attack of the Clones'', told [[Wikipedia:MTV|MTV]] that casting for the series was underway, and that some of her friends had auditioned for roles.<ref>{{WebCite|url=http://moviesblog.mtv.com/2009/03/09/exclusive-star-wars-live-action-tv-series-casting-underway|text=EXCLUSIVE: 'Star Wars' Live-Action TV Series Casting Underway|work=[[Wikipedia:MTV|MTV]]|archivedate=20090310171358|nolive=1}}</ref> However, [[Star Wars Insider 109|''Star Wars Insider'' 109]] claimed that scripts had yet to be written at that point, and would precede any earnest casting efforts, contradicting Byrne's claims.<ref>{{InsiderCite|109|Launchpad|Launch Pad}}</ref>

==Development==
{{Quote|It's a completely different kind of idea, which is risky. But that's the only reason I'm doing it. Some people will inevitably say, 'It's not what I think of as ''Star Wars''.' So who knows, it may work or it may not.|George Lucas|<ref name="TF 140" />}}
Prior to the release of the original ''Star Wars'' film in [[1977]], rumors began circulating that a TV series would be produced based on the film.<ref>[[Starlog (magazine)|Starlog]] #7</ref><ref>[[Starlog (magazine)|Starlog]] #18</ref><ref name="Starlog 90">[[Starlog (magazine)|Starlog]] #90</ref> Although such a project never came to fruition, [[George Lucas]] became involved (to varying degrees) in three live-action ''Star Wars'' television productions: ''[[The Star Wars Holiday Special]]'', ''[[Caravan of Courage: An Ewok Adventure]]'', and ''[[Ewoks: The Battle for Endor]]''. While the ''Holiday Special'' was a critical failure, both ''Ewok'' films won Emmy awards and had a positive critical reaction. In each case, the networks saw the productions as [[Wikipedia:Television pilot#Backdoor pilots|backdoor pilots]] for possible television series, though Lucas wasn't interested.<ref>''Filmfax'' #69/70, October 1998/January 1999</ref><ref>[[Starlog (magazine)|Starlog]] #89</ref> From [[1992]] to [[1996]], Lucas produced the television series [[Wikipedia:The Young Indiana Jones Chronicles|''The Young Indiana Jones Chronicles'']], during which he developed a love of making television.<ref name="cs">{{WebCite|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/movies/features/42983-exclusive-a-rare-sit-down-with-mr-george-lucas|text=Exclusive: A Rare Sit-Down with Mr. George Lucas|author=Edward Douglas|date=2008-03-17|work=[https://www.comingsoon.net ComingSoon.net]|archivedate=20180618184617}}</ref>

In late [[2004]], rumors again began to circulate of a live-action ''Star Wars'' series in development.<ref>{{WebCite|url=https://variety.com/2004/scene/markets-festivals/lucasfilm-expresses-interest-in-tv-1117911730|text=Lucasfilm expresses interest in TV|author=Alison James|date=2004-10-10|work=[[Wikipedia:Variety (magazine)|''Variety'']]|archivedate=20201007113337}}</ref><ref>{{WebCite|url=http://theforce.net/holonet/story/Anthony_Daniels_Talks_Star_Wars_TV_Series_88483.asp|text=Anthony Daniels Talks Star Wars TV Series|date=2004-12-23|work=[[TheForce.net]]|archivedate=20130309125553}}</ref><ref>{{WebCite|url=http://theforce.net/holonet/story/Star_Wars_TV_Series_Rumours_88291.asp|text=Star Wars TV Series Rumours|date=2004-12-11|work=[[TheForce.net]]|archivedate=20160311002453}}</ref><ref>{{WebCite|url=http://showbiz.sky.com/No-U-Turn-For-Lucas-On-Star-Wars|text=No U-Turn For Lucas On Star Wars|date=2004-09-22|work=[[Wikipedia:Sky Group|Sky]]|archivedate=20100814151935|nolive=1}}</ref><ref>{{WebCite|url=https://variety.com/2004/scene/markets-festivals/lucasfilm-expresses-interest-in-tv-1117911730|text=Lucasfilm expresses interest in TV|author=Alison James|date=2004-10-10|work=[[Wikipedia:Variety (magazine)|''Variety'']]|archivedate=20201007113337}}</ref> Lucas officially announced his plans for a live-action ''Star Wars'' television series at Celebration III, saying "We probably won't start that until sometime next year." He also spoke of plans for [[Star Wars: The Clone Wars|a new animated television series]] set during the [[Clone Wars]], which he expected to be produced first.<ref name="maker" /><ref>''[[Star Wars: The Ultimate Visual Guide]]''</ref> Also at the event, Rick McCallum elaborated; "He [George] envisions somewhere like 100 hours between Episode III and Episode IV."<ref name="RM" /> However, at [[2007]]'s [[Celebration Europe (2007)|Celebration Europe]], McCallum claimed that the plan was to produce "up to 400 episodes".<ref name="mc-ce" /> He also revealed that "I've had three conceptual artists working on it now for about seven months."<ref name="mc-ce" /><ref name="rictfn">{{WebCite|url=http://www.theforce.net/celebration/story/CE_Panel_Rick_McCallum_Producing_The_Prequels_107457.asp|text=CE Panel: Rick McCallum - Producing The Prequels|date=2007-07-15|work=[[TheForce.net]]|archivedate=20160311030531}}</ref> The original plan was for the first season to be entirely written and produced before shopping the series to broadcast networks; After a network was committed, work would commence on the following seasons.<ref name="2TV" /><ref>{{WebCite|url=http://ew.com/article/2008/03/18/george-lucas-star-wars-plan|text=George Lucas' 'Star Wars' plan|author=Joshua Rich|date=2008-03-18|work=''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''|archivedate=20170113074440}}</ref>

===Writing===
{{Quote|We'd go gather at Skywalker Ranch periodically, every couple of months, and break stories and write scripts for this proposed series that George was interested in. And George was in the ring with us every day. And it was a fascinating, amazing experience.|Ronald D. Moore|<ref name="Ron Moore" />}}
Lucas and McCallum (and, according to writer Matthew Grahman, the show's associate producer Steve Irwin<ref name="Graham Interview" />) interviewed over 200 prospective "writers of real significance" from all over the world—including [[Wikipedia:England|England]], the [[Wikipedia:United States|United States]], [[Wikipedia:Paris|Paris]], [[Wikipedia:Prague|Prague]], [[Wikipedia:Budapest|Budapest]] and [[Wikipedia:Australia|Australia]].<ref>{{WebCite|url=http://hollywoodinsider.ew.com/2007/10/star-wars-the-s.html|text=Is Lucas' 'Star Wars' TV series preparing for takeoff?|author=Lynette Rice|date=2007-10-12|work=''[[Entertainment Weekly]]|archivedate=20071015100952}}</ref><ref name="ns">{{InsiderCite|96|Com-Scan}}</ref> McCallum remarked, "It's about who's talented, who's got the strength to challenge George and also, much more importantly, what's the dynamics of the five or six people. If they can let go of their ego and work toward a specific goal. Sometimes you think 'I'm sick of writing alone.' Everyone has their ebb and flow. We're trying to get everyone in their peak."<ref>{{WebCite|url=http://fractalmatter.com/main/?p=732|text=Producing the Galaxy Part 1|work=Fractal Matter|archivedate=20071014231027|nolive=1}}</ref> Writers from [[Wikipedia:Battlestar Galactica (2004 TV series)|''Battlestar Galactica'']], [[Wikipedia:Heroes (TV series)|''Heroes'']], and [[Wikipedia:Lost (TV series)|''Lost'']], as well as those from the ''Star Wars'' books and comics, were considered as part of the final interview process in late 2007.<ref>{{WebCite|url=http://www.tmz.com/2007/06/09/star-wars-revenge-of-the-writers|text="Star Wars" -- Revenge of the Writers|date=2007-06-09|work=[[Wikipedia:TMZ|TMZ]]|archivedate=20181204201624}}</ref><ref name="Reunion2" /> In the end, six writers were hired<ref name="inn" />—including [[Terry Cafolla]], [[Wikipedia:Chris Chibnall|Chris Chibnall]],<ref name="Graham Interview" /> [[Louise Fox]], [[Tony McNamara]], [[Fiona Seres]],<ref name="Saga's far, far from over" /> [[Matthew Graham]],<ref name="Exclusive" /> Ronald D. Moore,<ref name="EW 2013" /><ref name="Ron Moore" /> and [[Stephen Scaia]]<ref name="Scaia Kickstarter" /><ref name="TFN Scaia" />—and were expected to start work in November 2007.<ref name="Reunion2" /> Current [[Wikipedia:Doctor Who (TV series)|''Doctor Who'']] writer [[Wikipedia:Russell T Davies|Russell T Davies]] was asked to write for the show, but turned it down due to his desire to do his own projects in a different style to both franchises; however, he did claim to be jealous of whoever ended up being hired.<ref>{{BookCite|author=Russell T Davies; Benjamin Cook|text=[[w:c:tardis:The Writer's Tale|The Writer's Tale]]|publisher=[[Wikipedia:BBC Books|BBC Books]]|date=2008|isbn=978-1-84607-571-1}}</ref>

After the writers were hired, story outlines took shape over the next three months.<ref name="toche" /> McCallum expected the first writing conference to occur in late 2007,<ref name="ns" /><ref name="inn" /> and sessions had began by August 2008.<ref name="mtv" /> The writers worked closely with the art department (including concept artist [[Erik Tiemens]]<ref name="inn" />), which had been working to design sets, environments, vehicles and aliens since 2007.<ref>''Total Film'' magazine, May 2008 issue, p. 138</ref><ref name="EW 2013" /> Ronald D. Moore commented on the writing process: "The scripts were written as if money was no object. George was like, 'Don't worry about it.' [Producer Rick McCallum] would groan and put his head in his hands periodically. So for us it was like, 'Okay, f–k it, let's write whatever we want.'"<ref name="EW 2014">{{WebCite|url=https://ew.com/article/2014/01/09/outlander-ron-moore-interview|text='Outlander': New photo and Ron Moore interview|author=James Hibberd|date=2014-01-09|work=''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''|archivedate=20191027023017}}</ref> … "His mandate on the scripts were: 'Think big. Don't have any worries. We'll make it. Budget is no object.' So we wrote these gigantic pieces."<ref name="Moore-inverse" /> Lucas originally wanted a season's worth of 25 scripts, but eventually extended this to 50 (i.e. two season's worth, with 25 episodes per season).<ref name="Graham Interview" /> Writer Matthew Graham described the writers as two teams that Lucas played off of each other: Those who were big ''Star Wars'' fans, and those who weren't as familiar with the franchise.<ref name="SFX336">"Going Underground", SFX 336</ref> Moore later told collider.com: "And what happened was, you know, we wrote the scripts and then George said 'OK, this is enough for now, and then I'll get back to you. I want to look into all the production things.' And then time went by and like a year or something after that is when he sold Lucasfilm to Disney."<ref name="Moore 2020" /> In the end, fifty hours worth of episodes plus a "[[Wikipedia:Television film|movie-of-the-week]]" were written,<ref name="TFN G4">{{WebCite|url=http://theforce.net/latestnews/story/George_Lucas_Talks_SW_LiveAction_Series_138409.asp|text=George Lucas Talks ''SW'' Live-Action Series|author=Eric Geller|date=2011-05-24|work=[[TheForce.net]]|archivedate=20200608202402}}</ref><ref name="IGN postponed">{{WebCite|url=https://www.ign.com/videos/2010/09/21/lucas-gives-update-on-star-wars-live-action-series|text=Lucas Gives Update on Star Wars Live-Action Series|date=2010-09-21|work=[[Wikipedia:IGN|''IGN'']]|archivedate=20200202083352}}</ref><ref name="LucasMovieWeb" /> all in various stages of development.<ref name="Graham Interview" /> In a January [[2012]] interview with [[Wikipedia:IGN|IGN]], McCallum revealed the working title to be ''Underworld'',<ref name="TFN1-9-12" /> which had originally served as the working title for an early concept for ''Star Wars: The Force Unleashed''.<ref>''[[The Art and Making of Star Wars: The Force Unleashed]]''</ref> McCallum denied this the next day,<ref> {{WebCite|url=https://www.ign.com/videos/2012/05/20/rick-mccallum-star-wars-tv-show-still-coming|text=Rick McCallum: Star Wars TV Show Still Coming|date=2012-05-20|work=[[Wikipedia:IGN|''IGN'']]|archivedate=20190426181446}}</ref> though he later told ''Entertainment Weekly'' that it was indeed the working title.<ref>{{WebCite|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2012/01/11/star-wars-live-action-tv-series-2|text=What's going on with that live-action 'Star Wars' TV series? EW found out|author=Christian Blauvelt|date=2012-01-11|work=''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''|archivedate=20160410055736}}</ref>

===Filming===
{{Quote|So imagine an hour's episode with more digital animation and more visual effects and more complicated in terms of set design and costume design than a two-hour movie that takes us three years to make, and we have to do that every week and we only have $5 million to do it. That's our challenge.|Rick McCallum|<ref name="COL (2012/01)" />}}
McCallum expected that he and Lucas would approach the series in a similar manner as they had ''The Young Indiana Jones Chronicles''.<ref name="C3S2" /><ref>{{WebCite|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/4484915.stm|text=Star Wars to become new TV series|date=2005-04-26|work=[[Wikipedia:BBC|BBC]]|archivedate=20181216120810}}</ref> Like on that earlier series, they hoped to give each episode the look of a feature film, with feature-level production values and visual effects on a television budget.<ref name="mc-ce" /> Lucas also talked of using the show as a template for how he would approach "more personal films" that he hoped to create.<ref name="toche" /> In 2005, Lucas stated his intentions to shoot the series using consumer-level cameras,<ref>{{WebCite|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/search/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1001096310|text=Future of entertainment|date=2005-09-13|work=[[Wikipedia:The Hollywood Reporter|''The Hollywood Reporter'']]|archivedate=20090623123912|nolive=1}}</ref> which McCallum said would be high-definition cameras.<ref name="RM" /> In late 2009, Lucas and McCallum invited filmmaker Phillip Bloom to [[Skywalker Ranch]] to advise on using different types of cameras for pick-up photography on [[Wikipedia:Red Tails|''Red Tails'']], and for the live-action series.<ref>Bloom, Phillip {{WebCite|url=http://philipbloom.net/2009/12/12/skywalker|text=The tale of Lucasfilm, Skywalker Ranch, Red Tails, Star Wars and Canon DSLRs on a 40 foot screen!|author=Philip Bloom|date=2009-12-12|work=[https://philipbloom.net Philip Bloom]|archivedate=20120625105457}}</ref> Lucas expected that, in producing the show, he would "do what would typically cost $20 million, for $1 million."<ref>{{WebCite|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117926854?categoryid=1009&cs=1&query=clone+and+wars&display=clone+wars|text=Lucas touts tube moves – Co. already at work on two 'Star' spin-off skeins|author=David S. Cohen|date=2005-08-01|work=[[Wikipedia:Variety (magazine)|''Variety'']]|archivedate=20071012140017}}</ref> According to IESB, McCallum has said that each episode will have a budget of 2-4 million dollars.<ref>{{WebCite|url=http://iesb.net/index.php?option=com_ezine&task=read&page=1&category=8&article=2673|text=Help Wanted: Lucasfilm is Looking for Star Wars TV Writers!|author=Ronnie Adams; Robert Sanchez|date=2007-06-09|work=IESB.net|archivedate=20071013211022|nolive=1}}</ref>

Principal photography was planned to take place all around the world, with a likely base in [[Wikipedia:Sydney|Sydney, Australia]].<ref name="RM" /><ref>{{WebCite|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/4808746.stm|text=Star Wars series to run and run|date=2006-03-15|work=[[Wikipedia:BBC|BBC]]|archivedate=20200915110303}}</ref><ref name="ns" /> In respect to the stunts, [[prequel trilogy]] stunt coordinators [[Nick Gillard]] and [[Kyle Rowling]] expressed interest in 2006 in working on the series as fighting directors.<ref>{{WebCite|url=https://starwarsinterviews.com/star-wars-crew/prequel-trilogy-star-wars-crew/kyle-rowling-fight-director|text=Kyle Rowling (Fight Director)|author=[[Dennis Pellegrom]]|date=2006|work=[[Star Wars Interviews]]|archivedate=20221209070435|nolive=1}}</ref> On the other hand, prequel trilogy special effects technician [[Matt Sloan]] hinted the possibility to return in order to do the series' visual effects.<ref>{{WebCite|url=https://starwarsinterviews.com/prequel-trilogy/episode-ii-attack-of-the-clones/matt-sloan-plo-koon|text=Matt Sloan (Plo Koon)|author=[[Dennis Pellegrom]]|date=2010-05|work=[[Star Wars Interviews]]|archivedate=20220930160653|nolive=1}}</ref> McCallum originally expected production to begin in either [[2008]] or 2009.<ref>{{WebCite|url=https://starwarsinterviews.com/star-wars-crew/prequel-trilogy-star-wars-crew/rick-mccallum-producer|text=Rick McCallum (Producer)|author=[[Dennis Pellegrom]]|date=2007-04|work=[[Star Wars Interviews]]|archivedate=20230205201645|nolive=1}}</ref><ref name="toche" /><ref name="ns" /><ref name="inn" /> He expected the first season to consist of thirteen-to-sixteen episodes, shot over a one-to-two-year time period.<ref name="ns" /> In March 2009, preliminary casting was still underway; a Lucasfilm representative claimed at the time that official casting would begin once the scripts were complete and that the series would not go into production until 2010.<ref name="lyons">{{WebCite|url=http://hollywoodinsider.ew.com/2009/03/star-wars-serie.html?xid=rss-feed-tvwatch-%27Star+Wars%27+series…still+far%2C+far+away|text=Star Wars live-action series…still far, far away|author=Margaret Lyons|date=2009-03-10|work=''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''|archivedate=20090313024710}}</ref> In a June 2011 interview, McCallum said that the show would most likely be filmed in the Czech Republic, a location used multiple times by LucasFilm for various productions.<ref name="Czechposition.com" /> Reportedly, [[Jim Marquand]], son of [[Star Wars: Episode VI Return of the Jedi|''Star Wars'': Episode VI ''Return of the Jedi'']] director [[Richard Marquand]], was hired as one of the directors.<ref>{{WebCite|url=http://www.liverpooldailypost.co.uk/liverpool-life-features/liverpool-arts/2008/02/28/jim-marquand-star-wars-memories-and-a-scouse-sense-of-humour-64375-20536913|text=Jim Marquand: Star Wars memories and a Scouse sense of humour|author=Greg O’Keeffe|date=2008-02-28|work=[https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk Liverpool Echo]|archivedate=20080303050239}}</ref> McCallum expected that each episode of the series would have its own original score,<ref name="inn" /> and hoped that [[John Williams]] would return as composer.<ref name="Reunion2" />

At a [[2010]] screening of ''The Empire Strikes Back'' in [[Wikipedia:Chicago, Illinois|Chicago, Illinois]], Lucas announced that the series was "on hold" due to budget concerns.<ref name="rebelscum">
{{Rebelscum|url=story/front/TESB_30th_Anniversary_Screening_131186.asp|text=TESB 30th Anniversary Screening|date=2010-05-10|archivedate=20200922123639}}</ref> Lucas and McCallum later elaborated that the scripts were prohibitively expensive for television, and that the show was put on hold in order to wait on technology to develop to the point that costs could be kept relatively low.<ref name="TFN G4" /><ref name="IGN postponed" /><ref name="Czechposition.com" /><ref name="COL (2012/01)" /><ref name="TFN1-9-12" /><ref name="LucasMovieWeb" /> Lucas had long planned to build an expansion to his Lucas Valley property called Grady Ranch, which would have been "a digital media production facility for movies and television."<ref>{{WebCite|url=http://www.pephousing.org/gradyranch|text=Grady Ranch|work=[https://www.pephousing.org PEP Housing]|archivedate=20160311212128}}</ref> However, in early 2012, Marin County rejected the project due to concerns over traffic and noise.<ref>{{WebCite|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/04/10/lucasfilm-abandons-grady-ranch_n_1416574.html|text=Lucasfilm Abandons Grady Ranch Project|author=Terence Chea|date=2012-06-10|work=[[Wikipedia:HuffPost|''The Huffington Post '']]|archivedate=20160311155026}}</ref> According to [[Pablo Hidalgo]], this marked the end of the show as a viable project.<ref>{{Twitter|pablohidalgo|status/1084883854249189377|[[Pablo Hidalgo]]|quote=1313 as a show evaporated the second Grady Ranch as a production facility was rejected by the county.|archivefile=File:PabloTweet1-14-2019.png}}</ref> In June 2012, McCallum also credited the logistics of the television market as one of the reasons for shelving ''Underworld''.<ref name="Dennis Potter">{{WebCite|url=https://www.denofgeek.com/movies/rick-mccallum-interview-dennis-potter-star-wars-tv-series-george-lucas-red-tails|text=Rick McCallum interview: Dennis Potter, Star Wars TV series, George Lucas & Red Tails|author=James Peaty|date=2012-06-03|work=[[Wikipedia:Den of Geek|''Den of Geek'']]|archivedate=20220613222742}}</ref>

On [[October 30]], [[2012]], [[The Walt Disney Company]] announced an agreement to acquire Lucasfilm, including the rights to the ''Star Wars'' franchise.<ref name="WDC (2012/10)">{{DisneyCompany|url=disney-news/press-releases/2012/10/disney-acquire-lucasfilm-ltd|text=DISNEY TO ACQUIRE LUCASFILM LTD.}}</ref> In a conference call following the press release, Disney expressed interest in the potential of a ''Star Wars'' television series, but did not go into details.<ref name="IGN (2012/10)">{{WebCite|url=https://www.ign.com/articles/2012/10/31/star-wars-tv-disney-xd-will-air-future-programming|text=Star Wars TV: Disney XD Will Air Future Programming|author=Eric Goldman|date=2012-10-31|work=[[Wikipedia:IGN|''IGN'']]|archivedate=20191113075842}}</ref> Soon after, it was announced that McCallum had retired from Lucasfilm.<ref>{{SW|url=news/an-independent-future-for-rick-mccallum|text=An Independent Future for Rick McCallum}}</ref><ref>{{WebCite|url=https://ew.com/article/2012/12/02/star-wars-rick-mccallum-leaving-lucasfilm|text='Star Wars' producer Rick McCallum officially leaving Lucasfilm|author=Adam B. Vary|date=2012-12-02|work=''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''|archivedate=20200803104348}}</ref> In [[January]] 2013, [[ABC Television Network|ABC]] president [[Wikipedia:Paul Lee (television executive)|Paul Lee]] told ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' that the live-action ''Star Wars'' series was being reevaluated for production.<ref name="EW 2013" /> This was confirmed by [[Wikipedia:Bob Iger|Bob Iger]] that March.<ref>{{WebCite|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2013-03-07/how-disney-bought-lucasfilm-and-its-plans-for-star-wars|text=How Disney Bought Lucasfilm—and Its Plans for 'Star Wars'|author=Devin Leonard|date=2013-03-08|work=[[Wikipedia:Bloomberg News|Bloomberg]]|archivedate=20200820164831}}</ref> That August, Lee again visited the topic of a ''Star Wars'' live-action series; "We've started conversations. I'd love to go there. I'm a particular fan of Lucasfilm. It's an amazing world".<ref>{{WebCite|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/tvandradioblog/2013/aug/14/star-wars-tv-series-disney|text=A Star Wars TV series may be in the pipeline again, but will it work?|author=Luke Holland|date=2013-08-14|work=[[Wikipedia:The Guardian|''The Guardian'']]|archivedate=20190806102356}}</ref><ref name="Reuters 8-13">{{WebCite|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/abc-starwars/abc-in-talks-to-develop-tv-shows-based-on-star-wars-characters-idUSL1N0G50CB20130804|text=ABC in talks to develop TV shows based on 'Star Wars' characters|date=2012-08-04|work=[[Wikipedia:Reuters|Reuters]]|archivedate=20190911130401}}</ref> Other ABC executives, however, later reiterated this in [[2016]] and [[2017]].<ref>{{WebCite|url=https://variety.com/2016/tv/news/star-wars-tv-series-abc-1201830573|text='Star Wars' TV Series Still a Possibility, Per ABC Boss: 'We Have Had Conversations'|author=Laura Prudom|date=2016-08-04|work=[[Wikipedia:Variety (magazine)|''Variety'']]|archivedate=20200701223441}}</ref><ref>{{WebCite|url=http://variety.com/2016/tv/news/abc-chief-on-networks-future-more-marvel-more-procedurals-and-maybe-star-wars-1201830532|text=ABC Chief on Network's Future: More Marvel, More Procedurals and Maybe 'Star Wars'|author=Daniel Holloway|date=2016-08-04|work=[[Wikipedia:Variety (magazine)|''Variety'']]|archivedate=20190728015358}}</ref><ref>{{WebCite|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/ben-sherwood-interview-star-wars-tv-series-primetime-plans-more-928151|text=Disney/ABC TV's Ben Sherwood on a 'Star Wars' Series, "Mistakes" in Michael Strahan's 'Live' Exit and Bob Iger's Future|author=Marisa Guthrie|date=2016-09-14|work=[[Wikipedia:The Hollywood Reporter|''The Hollywood Reporter'']]|archivedate=20200515221905}}</ref><ref>{{WebCite|url=https://ew.com/tv/2017/01/10/abc-scandal-free-fall-lineup-once-upon-time|text=ABC chief addresses ''Scandal''-free fall lineup and the future of OUAT|author=Lynette Rice|date=2016-01-10|work=''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''|archivedate=20200302015222}}</ref> In December [[2015]], [[Kathleen Kennedy]] told [[Wikipedia:/Film|Slashfilm]] that Lucasfilm had been looking at the material for both ''Underworld'' and the canceled video game ''[[Star Wars: 1313]]'', and that those projects may still be developed.<ref>{{WebCite|url=https://www.slashfilm.com/star-wars-tv-show|text=Lucasfilm Still Looking At George Lucas' Live Action Star Wars TV Show And Star Wars 1313|author=Peter Sciretta|date=2015-12-09|work=[[Wikipedia:/Film|''/Film'']]|archivedate=20200817070947}}</ref> In August 2017, Disney announced that it was removing its ''Star Wars'' and Marvel content from Netflix, in favor of its own new streaming service that would also include new content created exclusively for the service.<ref>{{WebCite|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/disney-pull-movies-netflix-launch-streaming-service-1027793|text=Disney to Pull Movies From Netflix, Launch Streaming Service|author=Paul Bond|date=2017-08-08|work=[[Wikipedia:The Hollywood Reporter|''The Hollywood Reporter'']]|archivedate=20200828153111}}</ref> On [[November 9]], 2017, [[Wikipedia:Variety (magazine)|''Variety'']] reported that Disney chairman and CEO Bob Iger revealed during the company's quarterly earnings call that Disney was planning a live-action ''Star Wars'' TV series entitled ''[[The Mandalorian]]'', which debuted at the end of [[2019]] on its streaming service [[Disney+]].<ref name="Disney Streaming">{{WebCite|url=http://variety.com/2017/biz/news/star-wars-tv-series-disney-streaming-service-1202611408|text=New 'Star Wars' Trilogy in Works With Rian Johnson, TV Series Also Coming to Disney Streaming Service|author=Cynthia Littleton|date=2017-11-09|work=[[Wikipedia:Variety (magazine)|''Variety'']]|archivedate=20171110013244}}</ref> This series, together with additional ''Star Wars'' series that followed it such as ''[[The Book of Boba Fett]]'', was produced with a new technology called Stagecraft (informally known as "The Volume"). ''Variety'' observed that Stagecraft fulfilled Lucas' desire for a cost-effective technology to produce a ''Star Wars'' TV show.<ref name="The Show That Almost Was">{{WebCite|url=https://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2022/05/star-wars-may-the-4th-underworld|text=Star Wars: Underworld—The Galactic TV Show That Almost Was|author=Anthony Breznican|date=2022-05-04|work=[[Wikipedia:Variety (magazine)|''Variety'']]|archivedate=20220613220033}}</ref>

==Release and legacy==
[[File:SWtimeline.jpg|thumb|200px|A 2007 promotional poster.]]
{{Quote|It's something we're very precious with at Lucasfilm because it represents this big piece of work that George did before he basically left Star Wars. We're constantly poring over it because, to me, even though it remains unproduced, the ideas in it are what makes it so valuable. The ideas are real and true to Star Wars because it's created by George.|[[Dave Filoni]] to ''Variety''|<ref name="The Show That Almost Was" />}}
In a 2006 interview, Steve Sansweet said that he expected the series to be released "toward the end of the decade." He gave the time period until release to be "about 3 years."<ref>{{WebCite|url=http://www.movieweb.com/tv/news/90/11090.php|text=EXCLUSIVE INTERVIEW: Steve Sansweet Talks About the Upcoming ''Star Wars'' TV Shows!|author=Reedy, Stephen|date=2006-02-15|archivedate=20080807173807}}</ref> A teaser image for the series was shown at [[Wikipedia:Toy Fair|Toy Fair]] 2007, advertising the next three years of ''Star Wars'': the 30th anniversary of the saga and the release of ''The Force Unleashed'' in 2007 (which was ultimately pushed back to 2008), the new ''Clone Wars'' TV series in 2008, and the live-action series in 2009.<ref name="toyfair">{{WebCite|url=https://www.jeditemplearchives.com/swexperience/toyfair2007/hasbro/pages/01intro-007.html|text=Toy Fair 2007 Promotional|archivedate=20190509233542}}</ref><ref>{{Rebelscum|url=TF2007/SWtimeline.jpg|text=Rebelscum|archivedate=20180530232700}}</ref><ref>{{WebCite|url=http://wizarduniverse.com/_images_/003443/IMG_9163.jpg|text=Wizard Entertainment|archivedate=20070223052357}}</ref><ref>{{WebCite|url=http://www.wizarduniverse.com/magazine/toyfare/003443978.cfm?popup=1|text=Wizard Entertainment|archivedate=20071111182317}}</ref> Rick McCallum expected the series to be released simultaneously worldwide and to be broadcast on cable.<ref name="toche" /><ref name="Reunion2" /> Both Disney and [[Wikipedia:News Corporation|News Corp]] were rumored to have shown interest in acquiring broadcast rights for the show, with the former offering ABC and [[Wikipedia:ABC Family|ABC Family]] and the latter offering [[Wikipedia:Fox Broadcasting Company|FOX]] and [[Wikipedia:FX (TV network)|FX]].<ref>{{WebCite|url=http://jimhillmedia.com/editor_in_chief1/b/jim_hill/archive/2007/08/17/are-george-lucas-and-the-walt-disney-company-getting-ready-to-expand-their-rebel-alliance.aspx|text=Are George Lucas and the Walt Disney Company getting ready to expand their (Rebel) Alliance|author=Hill, Jim|date=2007-08-27|work=jimhillmedia.com|archivedate=20200803015900}}</ref> Additionally, Lucas voiced his interest in distributing the series via the Internet—specifically [[StarWars.com]].<ref>{{WebCite|url=http://allthingsd.com/20070821/george-lucas-the-entire-d5-interview-with-walt-mossberg-and-kara-swisher|text=George Lucas: The Entire D5 Interview With Walt Mossberg and Kara Swisher|work=All Things D|archivedate=20170102045234}}</ref>

At 2005's Celebration III, Lucas told audiences that if the live-action series (along with the new ''Clone Wars'' animated series) was successful, more series could follow.<ref name="C3S2" /> At 2007's Celebration Europe, McCallum explained that "One of the ideas is that we'll have multiple series going on in about two or three years' time."<ref name="mc-ce" /> McCallum said he hoped that after the series' second or third year, a character could have their own spin-off series, and by the fourth or fifth year, the production staff could have at least five separate series running.<ref name="ns" /> Lucas described the series as "one show that will split into four shows, focusing on different characters."<ref>{{WebCite|url=http://tv.ign.com/articles/770/770160p2.html|text=Paley Fest: George Lucas Gives Details on the Star Wars TV Shows|work=IGN|archivedate=20070308091900}}</ref><ref>{{WebCite|url=http://uk.ign.com/articles/2007/03/06/paley-fest-george-lucas-gives-details-on-the-star-wars-tv-shows|text=Paley Fest: George Lucas Gives Details on the ''Star Wars'' TV Shows|author=Goldman, Eric|date=2007-04-05|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20190420181647/https://www.ign.com/articles/2007/03/06/paley-fest-george-lucas-gives-details-on-the-star-wars-tv-shows}}</ref>

Comments from Lucasfilm employees (such as [[Sue Rostoni]] and [[Jim Ward]]) had hinted that tie-ins such as spin-off books and video games were planned.<ref>{{SWBoards|url=thread.jspa?threadID=222689&start=5100#16739424|thread=Books, Comics, & Television VIPs|user=[[Sue Rostoni]]|date=2007-06-25|time=7:52 PM|quote=The animated and live action series are separate and will be contracted out separately -- discussions haven't begun for either of these yet.}}</ref><ref>{{Hyperspace|url=hyperspace/member/audiocast/audio/SW_dvdpressevent_01_2005-10-07.mp3|text=''Revenge of the Sith'' DVD press event}}</ref><ref>{{WebCite|url=http://filmforce.ign.com/articles/657/657048p1.html|text=Star Wars Goes Live on the Small Screen|work=IGN|archivedate=20051013093449}}</ref><ref>{{WebCite|url=http://www.businessweek.com/innovate/content/nov2006/id20061122_709907.htm?campaign_id=rss_daily|text=There's More to Lucas Than Star Wars, You Know|work=BusinessWeek|archivedate=20071015070650}}</ref> The canceled video game ''[[Star Wars: 1313]]'' was originally conceived as a direct tie-in to ''Underworld'';<ref name="kotaku">{{WebCite|url=https://www.kotaku.com.au/2013/03/the-strange-status-of-star-wars-1313-a-hot-game-with-an-uncertain-future|text=The Strange Status Of Star Wars: 1313, A Hot Game With An Uncertain Future|author=Totilo, Stephen|date=2013-03-01|archivedate=20181113115255}}</ref> After ''Underworld'' was postponed in 2010 due to budget constraints, ''1313'' was altered to be its own distinct project. However, at George Lucas's request, the final game was to have still taken inspiration from elements of ''Underworld''.<ref name="kotaku" /> ''The Clone Wars'' introduced [[Level 1313]],<ref>{{SWArchive|url=explore/the-clone-wars/ep519|text="To Catch a Jedi" - The Clone Wars Episode Guide}}</ref> as well as the character [[Saw Gerrera]], who was also conceived for ''Underworld''.<ref>{{StarWarsShow|Filn82qphCA|New Rogue One Characters Revealed, LEGO Star Wars: The Freemaker Adventures | The Star Wars Show}}</ref> According to [[James Luceno]], [[Palpatine/Legends|Palpatine's]] first name, "Sheev" (which he revealed in his 2014 novel [[Tarkin (novel)|''Tarkin'']]), was reportedly created by Lucas for the show.<ref name="Full of Sith Luceno interview">50 min - 52 min mark: {{WebCite|url=http://fullofsith.com/archives/1214|text=Full of Sith|author=Tha Mike|date=2014-11-02|archivedate=20160506161120}}</ref>

The animated series ''[[Star Wars Rebels]]'' was influenced by ideas developed by Lucas for ''Underworld''.<ref>{{WebCite|url=http://www.theforce.net/story/front/SDCC_2014_Complete_Audio_From_Star_Wars_A_New_Dawn_Panel_159102.asp|text=SDCC 2014: Complete Audio From Star Wars: A New Dawn Panel|archivedate=20190830210911}}</ref> The [[Church of the Force]]—a background element related to [[Lor San Tekka]] from [[Star Wars: Episode VII The Force Awakens|''Star Wars'': Episode VII ''The Force Awakens'']]—was created by Lucas for ''Underworld''.<ref name="SWBW 53">{{WebCite|url=http://www.starwarsreport.com/2016/02/19/pablo-hidalgo-interview-swbw-53|text=''Pablo Hidalgo Interview'' – SWBW #53|author=Goins, Aaron|date=2016-02-19|format=[[Wikipedia:Podcast|Podcast]]|work=[http://www.starwarsreport.com The Star Wars Report]|archivedate=20180331234747}}</ref> [[John Knoll]] originally developed the concept for ''[[Rogue One: A Star Wars Story]]'' in the mid-[[2000]]s during the production of the [[prequel trilogy]], in the hopes that it could be an episode of the live-action series.<ref name="CEpanel">{{SWYouTube|QU9556YKZnU|Rogue One: A Star Wars Story Panel}}</ref> After the release of the prequels, [[Wikipedia:Zack Snyder|Zack Snyder]] was also developing a ''Star Wars'' story with Lucasfilm; After the Disney purchase, Snyder developed the project into the film [[Wikipedia:Rebel Moon|''Rebel Moon'']] (2023).<ref name="RebelMoon">{{WebCite|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/movies/movie-news/zack-snyder-sets-next-movie-sci-fi-adventure-rebel-moon-at-netflix-exclusive-1234978201|text=Zack Snyder Sets Next Movie, Sci-Fi Adventure ''Rebel Moon'', at Netflix (Exclusive)|date=2021-07-06|archivedate=20210706214524}}</ref><ref name="SnyderPitch">{{WebCite|url=https://www.digitalspy.com/movies/a36637102/zack-snyder-star-wars-movie|text=Zack Snyder confirms he was working on a ''Star Wars'' movie|author=Joe Anderton|date=2021-05-06|archivedate=20210605100611}}</ref> The film ''[[Solo: A Star Wars Story]]'' showed the first meeting between [[Han Solo]] and [[Chewbacca]] along with [[Landonis Balthazar Calrissian|Lando Calrissian]] losing the ''[[Millennium Falcon]]'' to Solo, two stories which were originally planned for ''Underworld''.<ref>{{WebCite|url=https://nerdist.com/star-wars-prequel-han-solo-chewbacca-bob-iger-confirms-lord-miller-report|text=The STAR WARS Prequel is a Chewbacca and Han Origin Story (Report)|author=Rachel Heine|date=2016-03-08|work=Nerdist|archivedate=20180616034500}}</ref> [[Wikipedia:Kratos (God of War)|Kratos's]] character arc from the [[2018]] [[Wikipedia:God of War (2018 video game)|''God of War'']] video game was inspired by the unproduced ''Underworld'' scripts. Former [[LucasArts]] developer [[Cory Barlog]] revealed that he read scripts at [[Skywalker Ranch]] that were written by writers of [[Wikipedia:24 (TV series)|''24'']] and [[Wikipedia:The Shield|''The Shield'']]. According to Barlog, "They made the Emperor a sympathetic figure who was wronged by this [...] heartless woman. She's this hardcore gangster, and she just totally destroyed him as a person. I almost cried while reading this. This is the Emperor, the lightning out of the fingers Emperor. That's something magical."<ref name="Barlog" />

Test footage of ''Underworld'' that [[Wikipedia:Stargate Studios|Stargate Studios]] created as a proof of concept in 2010 was discovered on Stargate Studios' Vimeo page in January [[2020]].<ref>{{YouTube|_tpTOwXVu8g|"Star Wars: Underworld" test footage + Making Of|channel/UC4PmvuFtwtwiF9GzXS2f9EA|holonet|archivedate=20200131210033}}</ref> It depicts a female [[Alliance to Restore the Republic|Rebel agent]] stealing plans for an Imperial Star Destroyer and setting off an electrical attack on Imperial stormtroopers.<ref>{{WebCite|url=https://www.polygon.com/tv/2020/1/30/21115878/star-wars-tv-show-underworld-george-lucas-footage|text=Footage reportedly from George Lucas' abandoned Star Wars: TV series surfaces|author=Goslin, Austen|date=2020-01-30|work=Polygon|archivedate=20200605152100}}</ref><ref>{{WebCite|url=https://io9.gizmodo.com/heres-the-real-deal-with-that-leaked-star-wars-footage-1841389155|text=Here's the Real Deal With That Leaked Star Wars Footage|author=Lussier, Germain|date=2020-02-03|work=io9|archivedate=20200821105742}}</ref>
